header.title: LA MYSTIQUE DIVINE, NATURELLE ET DIABOLIQUE - TOME IV: LA MYSTIQUE DIABOLIQUE
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Demonology, History of Magic

central_thesis: This volume provides an exhaustive analysis of 'diabolical mysticism' as a perversion and antithesis of divine mysticism. It posits that evil, originating from the sin of created intelligence, manifests in the physical and moral world through practices like magic, divination, and possession. The author details the historical and physiological mechanisms through which humans enter into intimate, often enslaving, relationships with demonic forces, emphasizing the contrast with the redemptive work of Christ and the Church's role in combatting these influences. The work seeks to understand these phenomena not as mere illusions but as tangible effects stemming from deliberate choices that open individuals to infernal powers, ultimately condemning such practices as fundamentally opposed to divine order.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE PREMIER: Comment le mal physique et moral se propage. Rapport de la magie et de la possession avec la première chute. Des deux cités. Des degrés de l'ascèse diabolique.
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the dualistic view of creation (light vs. darkness) and the human condition, noting how original sin introduced moral and physical evil. It links magic and possession to the first fall of angels and man, presenting them as continuations of a struggle between divine and diabolical influences. Yielding to evil progressively enslaves the human will and physical being, leading to a path of diabolical asceticism.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE II: L'ascèse diabolique considérée dans le domaine de la vie. Opposition de cette ascèse avec l'ascèse purgative. De la division des moyens physiques propres à exciter l'organisme.
structure_content.summary: This chapter differentiates diabolical asceticism from purgative (divine) asceticism. While divine asceticism aims to elevate the spirit by detaching it from the created, diabolical asceticism seeks to force entry into invisible realms by intensely exciting the physical organism. It categorizes the physical means used in diabolical asceticism: those acting on circulation/ganglia (ethereal elements, fumigations, vapors), those on the external skin (frictions, ointments), and those on internal skin (liquids, irritants).

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE III: Les initiations dans le paganisme. Les anciens mystères, bons et honnêtes à l'origine, n'ont pas tardé à dégénérer. On en trouve encore des restes dans les forêts de l'Amérique, chez les Virginiens, les Caraïbes, les Moxes, les Mexicains, les Péruviens; puis au nord de l'Asie, dans le pays des Jakutes; chez les Finnois et les Lapons.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores historical pagan initiations, noting their dual nature (sober vs. enthusiastic) and eventual degeneration into practices involving magic. Examples from indigenous American tribes (Virginians, Caraïbes, Moxes, Mexicains, Péruviens) and northern Asian groups (Jakutes, Finnois, Lapons) are provided, highlighting the use of hallucinogenic substances (visoccan, tabac, coca), physical endurance (fasting, torture), rhythmic dances, and evocations to achieve altered states and communicate with spirits, often leading to clairvoyance and memory loss.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE IV: Le mahométisme, ses mystères et ses initiations. Le suffisme pénètre dans les abstractions du Coran, et est représenté au dehors par l'ordre des derviches. Ceux-ci se partagent à Constantinople en deux classes, les danseurs et les hurleurs. Rapports remarquables sur les cheiks Ruffai de l'Inde. Explication de ces phénomènes.
structure_content.summary: This chapter discusses Mahometan mysticism, particularly Sufism and the Dervish orders (dancers and hurlers) in Constantinople and India (Ruffai sheikhs). It details their practices involving intense rhythmic dancing, chanting, smoking potent tobacco (tscherkesse), and consuming alcohol to induce ecstatic, trance-like states, leading to insensitivity to pain and extreme physical acts, such as self-mutilation with sabers and lances. These are presented as means to achieve a form of 'inspiration' or altered consciousness.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE V: Les initiations à la magie dans les temps chrétiens. La magie au moyen âge s'est cachée dans l'obscurité des grottes. De là elle a pénétré dans les cabanes du peuple. Des moyens magiques dont on se servait alors : de l'onguent des sorcières. Recherches faites à ce sujet par les théologiens, par les jurisconsultes, par les médecins et les naturalistes. Explication et expériences d'Helmond et de Davy. Des symptômes produits par ces onguents d'après les déclarations de ceux qui les ont éprouvés. Appréciation morale de ces moyens.
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines the evolution of magic in Christian times, from hidden practices in caves to popular witchcraft. It focuses on witches' ointments, describing their composition (hemlock, henbane, solanum, mandragora, aconite, bat blood, animal fat) and effects: inducing lethargy, vivid dreams of the Sabbath, altered perceptions, and temporary physical insensitivity. Accounts from theologians, jurists, and scientists (Helmont, Davy) are cited to explain these phenomena as either physical alterations or psychological illusions, with a moral condemnation of their use.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE VI: L'ascèse diabolique considérée dans le domaine moral. Des fausses doctrines que la cité du diable oppose à la cité de Dieu. Ces doctrines égalent la créature au Créateur, ou la mettent au-dessus de lui, ou enfin la considèrent comme la seule chose existante. Partant de l'incrédulité, elles mènent à la superstition, à la fausse magie naturelle, à la fausse divination et à la magie noire, qui sont les trois exercices ascétiques par lesquels l'homme est initié aux mystères de l'enfer.
structure_content.summary: This chapter delves into the moral dimension of diabolical asceticism, outlining false doctrines that elevate the creature above the Creator, leading to incredulity, superstition, false natural magic, divination, and black magic. These practices are depicted as steps towards a conscious union with the devil, fueled by pride and deceit, perverting genuine spirituality and creating a 'city of the devil' opposed to God.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE VII: Comment l'homme peut conjurer la nature. Différence de la vraie et de la fausse science. Des prétentions de celle-ci; de ce qu'il y a de vrai en elle. La superstition se rattache à la puissance indéfinie du nombre, du son et de la parole.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the human attempt to 'conjure' or control nature, contrasting true science (rooted in divine order) with false science/magic (rooted in human pride and illusion). It discusses the belief in the power of number, sound, and word (as in cabalistic practices) to influence celestial bodies and natural elements. This false science is seen as an attempt to usurp God's creative power, leading to illusions and the propagation of diabolical influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE VIII: De la divination, de ses diverses formes. De la faculté de voir au loin à l'aide d'un miroir ou de quelque fluide. Anciens récits sur ce point. Celui du poète Rist. Cas rapporté par Spengler. Récits des voyageurs modernes en Egypte. Explication de ces phénomènes. Des autres formes de divination. Cecco Esculano, célèbre astrologue du xive siècle.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details various forms of divination, particularly scrying (mirror, crystal, fluid). Historical accounts (Pausanias, Rist, Spengler) and modern examples from Egypt (Scheikh-Abda-el-Kader-el-Moghrebi) illustrate the use of children or predisposed individuals as mediums to see distant events or predict the future. The phenomena are explained as either supernatural influence or heightened natural clairvoyance induced by magnetic rapport or substances like fumigation, with a critical view on its scientific validity and moral implications.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE IX: De l'évocation des esprits, des anciennes formes de la théurgie. La nécromancie en Thessalie. Elle continue dans le christianisme. Ce qui est arrivé dans les derniers temps encore avec Jean Ferez, cité devant l'inquisition espagnole pour avoir évoqué le diable. Le triple ban de l'enfer de Faust. L'esprit du Tasse. Dangers de ces invocations; exemple de Th. Parkes.
structure_content.summary: This chapter discusses the evocation of spirits, from ancient theurgy and Thessalian necromancy to its persistence in Christian times. It contrasts this with true spiritual elevation, warning against the dangers of seeking power through independent spirit contact. Accounts such as Jean Ferez evoking the devil, Faust's 'Triple Ban,' and the spirit of Tasso are used to illustrate these practices and their potential for spiritual and physical harm, emphasizing the diabolical nature of forced spirit interactions.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE X: L'ascèse diabolique dans le domaine moral. Du mensonge et de l'imposture dans les choses de la vie intérieure. Comment certaines personnes feignent des états extraordinaires. Histoire de quatre moines de Berne en 1506. Contre-partie de cette histoire chez les protestants en Angleterre quarante ans plus tard. Le dominicain de Landsperg.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores deceit and imposture as moral aspects of diabolical asceticism, focusing on individuals feigning extraordinary states. It narrates historical cases like the four monks of Bern (1506) and a Protestant counterpart in England, highlighting how false miracles and deceptions were used to gain influence, promote specific doctrines, or cause scandal, demonstrating the demonic influence operating through human perversity and pride.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XI: De ceux qui ont feint d'être possédés. Histoire racontée par Pigrai en France. W. Perry en Angleterre. Somers et son exorciste Darrel.
structure_content.summary: This chapter continues the theme of feigned possession, presenting detailed cases to illustrate the cunning and deception involved. Examples include Pigrai's account from France and the case of W. Perry and his exorcist Darrel in England. These narratives expose how individuals imitate symptoms of possession for various motives, including seeking attention or material gain, and how experienced exorcists or investigators reveal these impostures through specific tests.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XII: De ceux qui par orgueil ont feint la sainteté. Comment, lorsque le mensonge est uni à la vanité et à l'orgueil, l'homme finit souvent par se persuader qu'il ne ment pas. Comment le mal se développe et arrive à son dernier terme. Histoire d'une religieuse de Cell près de Constance; d'une autre près de Lyon; de Catherine dans la Valteline; d'une femme de Gand, citée par Delrio; de Nicole de Reims; de François de la Croix au Pérou.
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines how pride, vanity, and self-deception lead individuals to feign sanctity. It describes the progressive self-delusion where a person, initially conscious of their lie, eventually believes their own manufactured spirituality. Historical accounts, such as the nun of Cell, women from Gand, Catherine in Valteline, and Nicole of Reims, illustrate the development of these false spiritual paths and their eventual exposure, often involving 'prophecies' and fabricated stigmas.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XIII: Comment la volupté se cache sous le masque de la sainteté. Histoire d'un provincial des Capucins et de dix-sept Béguines de Carthagène; du Carme Saulnier à Valognes en Normandie; du P. Girard à Toulon. Jugement sur tous ces faits.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the perversion of spirituality through sensuality and lust disguised as sanctity. It presents cases of ecclesiastics (like a Capuchin provincial, Carmelite Saulnier, and Father Girard) who exploited women (Beguines, Cadière) under the guise of spiritual direction, using 'mystical' experiences to fulfill criminal desires. The chapter analyzes how magnetic rapport and altered states can be manipulated for immoral ends, leading to scandals.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XIV: Du pacte avec le démon. L'union avec le démon produite par le péché originel a été détruite par la rédemption. Des causes qui unissent l'homme au démon. Chaque passion a son démon particulier. Des sept filles de Satan. De la pauvreté et des autres nécessités de la vie.
structure_content.summary: This chapter discusses the concept of a formal pact with the demon, contrasting it with the original sin and Christ's redemption. It explains how various passions (pride, avarice, disloyalty, envy, vanity, impurity, hatred) serve as 'links' to the demon, each associated with a specific infernal entity ('Satan's seven daughters'). Poverty and life's necessities can also push desperate individuals to seek demonic assistance, often leading to illusory gains and profound spiritual enslavement.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XV: Suites du pacte avec le diable. L'homme, en se donnant au démon, se sépare complètement de la cité de Dieu, et devient citoyen de la cité du diable.
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes the consequences of a pact with the devil, leading to a complete separation from God's 'city' and integration into the 'city of the devil.' This union involves a monstrous spiritual and physical rapport, where the human will becomes subservient to demonic desires, leading to increasing moral degradation and loss of spiritual freedom. The individual becomes an instrument of evil, reflecting the destructive nature of the infernal realm.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XVI: De l'obsession comme premier degré de la possession. Des gnomes ou farfadets. Histoire d'un gentilhomme de la Valteline et du surintendant Schupart.
structure_content.summary: This chapter defines obsession as the initial stage of demonic influence, distinguished from full possession. It describes subtle external disturbances (gnomes, farfadets) and mental agitation experienced by individuals who, through certain dispositions or moral failings, become accessible to preternatural influences. Cases like the gentleman from Valteline and Superintendent Schupart illustrate persistent external attacks and vexations by invisible entities, prefiguring deeper possession.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XVII: Les tentations considérées comme effets de l'obsession. Marie Crucifiée.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores intense temptations as a manifestation of obsession, using the example of Marie Crucifiée. It details her experiences of physical restraint, inability to speak, and forced consumption of foul substances, all attributed to demonic interference, especially around holy rituals like communion. The chapter highlights the demon's attempts to obstruct spiritual practices and induce despair, even while the individual maintains a strong will against the evil.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XVIII: Altération du tempérament par les influences vitales; par la faim ou la soif; par les mauvais traitements; par les maladies; par l'épilepsie; par les phases de la lune. Histoire d'un jeune homme du couvent d'Herzogenbusch; d'une jeune fille de Silésie; de Cath. Somnoata; de quatre sœurs à Modène.
structure_content.summary: This chapter focuses on how various physical and psychological factors (temperament, hunger, thirst, abuse, illness, epilepsy, lunar phases) can predispose individuals to demonic possession by altering their vital constitution. It presents cases, such as a young man from Herzogenbusch who gained prophetic abilities after eating a white leaf, and sisters from Modena who were tormented during specific moon phases, suggesting natural vulnerabilities that open doors to infernal influences.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XIX: Les influences spirituelles considérées dans leurs rapports avec la possession. Un simple regard, quelquefois même une simple plaisanterie, peut la produire. Des formes sous lesquelles le démon a coutume de paraître. Histoire de Jean Schmidt.
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines how spiritual influences, even subtle ones like a glance or a jest, can initiate possession, especially when an individual's 'spiritual dikes' are broken. It describes the various forms the demon can assume (animals, humans, shapeless shadows) to interact with the possessed, focusing on the story of Jean Schmidt, who became possessed after an encounter where the devil was depicted on a wall.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XX: Des causes occasionnelles de la possession du côté des démons. Des influences du paganisme. Du pouvoir de la malédiction. Histoire d'une famille de Césarée. Ives de Danguernano.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the direct causal role of demons in possession, specifically through pagan influences and the power of curses. It provides examples, such as a family in Caesarea cursed by an angry mother and Ives de Danguernano, who became possessed after his mother's malediction, demonstrating how specific negative actions or invocations can open individuals to immediate demonic attack and prolonged suffering.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXI: Le péché considéré comme venant du démon et retournant à lui. Dieu punit quelquefois par la possession les péchés commis contre lui ou contre ses saints, l'orgueil, l'envie, l'avarice, le vol sacrilège, la colère, quelquefois même des fautes légères. Souvent aussi la possession est une épreuve et non un châtiment. Prêtre de Vallombreuse.
structure_content.summary: This chapter considers sin as both originating from and leading back to the demon, with possession sometimes being a divine punishment or a trial for various sins (pride, envy, avarice, sacrilege, anger, even minor faults). Cases like the priest of Vallombreuse illustrate how hidden sins can cause demonic torment, highlighting the theological perspective on possession as a consequence or crucible for moral transgressions.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXII: De la durée de la possession. Histoire singulière et touchante de la bienheureuse Eustochie de Padoue.
structure_content.summary: This chapter investigates the duration and nature of demonic possession, presenting the case of the Blessed Eustochie of Padua as a remarkable example. Her lifelong possession, starting from childhood, is depicted as a divine trial for purification, during which she endured physical torment (wounds, beatings) but maintained spiritual purity and resistance to the demon, illustrating how long-term possession can serve a higher spiritual purpose.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXIII: Du nombre des démons dans la possession. Marie Garcia, en Espagne.
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines the concept of multiple demons possessing a single individual, often referred to as 'legion,' and how this is understood in theological and historical contexts. The case of Marie Garcia in Spain, who was tormented by many demons, is presented to illustrate this phenomenon, along with the idea that the number of demons and their hierarchy reflect the complexity of the possessed state.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXIV: Des altérations produites par la possession dans l'énergie des organes du mouvement. Marsitas.
structure_content.summary: This chapter focuses on the physical manifestations of possession related to the motor system, describing how demonic influence can alter bodily movements, leading to extraordinary strength, contortions, or paralysis. The case of Marsitas, from Jerusalem, is cited as an example of a possessed individual exhibiting immense physical power and violence, tearing chains and injuring people, before being cured through saintly intervention.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXV: Influence de la possession sur les sens. Des formes sous lesquelles le démon apparaît. L'abbé Hermann. Le moine Achard. Pasqualinus de Tondellis. Antoinette de Saint-Gaudence. Humiliana de Cerchis.
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores how possession influences the senses, leading to visible demonic apparitions and altered perceptions. It describes the various forms demons take (animals, humans, shadows) and how the possessed experience these phenomena. Examples include Abbot Hermann, monk Achard, Pasqualinus, Antoinette, and Humiliana, who all encountered demons in forms that evoked fear or, deceptively, comfort, often leading to physical or psychological torment.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXVI: Influence de la possession sur les facultés spirituelles. Les démons à Prémontré. Les possédés voient à distance.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the demon's influence on the spiritual faculties, particularly memory and imagination. It describes how possessed individuals often forget their actions during attacks and experience vivid, often terrifying, visions. The case of the canons of Prémontré, tormented by imaginary attackers and false prophecies, illustrates how the demon manipulates mental faculties and instills discord, sometimes leading to clairvoyance of distant events but distorted by infernal influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXVII: De la délivrance des possédés. L'Église considérée dans ses rapports avec les possédés. Comment ceux-ci ont horreur de tout ce qui tient à l'Église. Histoire d'une religieuse. Le diable parle par la bouche des enfants. Histoire touchante d'un enfant. La vérité arrachée au démon dans les possédés.
structure_content.summary: This chapter focuses on the process of deliverance from possession through the intervention of the Church. It highlights the possessed's inherent aversion to holy objects and rites. Accounts of nuns and children speaking with demonic voices, and the extraction of truth from demons through exorcism, demonstrate the Church's authority and methods, emphasizing the role of faith, prayer, and sacraments in breaking demonic ties.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXVIII: Polémique des possédés. Nicole Aubry. Une possédée calviniste. Une autre exorcisée par Luther. Les possédés discernent les choses saintes.
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines the 'polemic' aspect of possession, where demons use the possessed to engage in theological debates, particularly between Catholics and Protestants. Cases like Nicole Aubry and possessed individuals 'exorcised' by Luther are presented, illustrating how demons would speak in multiple languages, reveal hidden secrets, or even accuse individuals, creating confusion and challenging religious authority, yet often revealing a deeper spiritual truth.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXIX: De la puissance qu'a reçue l'Église de délivrer les possédés. Parthenius. Saint Yves. Saint Norbert. Saint Albert. Saint Jean de Salerne. Sainte Catherine de Sienne.
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the inherent power of the Church, through its priests and saints, to cast out demons. It emphasizes the 'antipathy' between the possessed and the Church, rooted in the opposition between divine and infernal realms. Examples of saints like Parthenius, Yves, Norbert, Albert, Jean de Salerne, and Catherine of Siena illustrate the effectiveness of their prayers, relics, and the cross in delivering the possessed, demonstrating God's consistent protection and the limited power of demons.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXX: De la puissance des prêtres dans les exorcismes : les sacrements et les sacramentaux. Saint Ursmar. La foi. La confession. L'eucharistie. Saint Bernard. Les reliques des saints. La croix.
structure_content.summary: This chapter elaborates on the specific means used by priests in exorcisms, including sacraments (confession, Eucharist) and sacramentals (holy water, relics, the cross). It describes how faith is crucial for both the exorcist and the possessed. Examples such as Saint Ursmar and Saint Bernard demonstrate how these sacred elements, by directly invoking God's power and breaking the spiritual ties of sin, effectively expel demons, often with dramatic physical manifestations.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXXI: Précautions à prendre dans l'emploi des exorcismes. Deux excès à éviter. Il faut d'abord constater la possession : il ne faut pas croire à toutes les paroles des possédés, ni aux accusations, ni aux menaces du démon. L'exorciste doit veiller sur soi-même. Histoire d'un prêtre, d'un exorciste, d'un chevalier.
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides crucial precautions for exorcists, warning against both excessive demonization (attributing all ills to demons) and excessive materialism (denying demonic influence altogether). It stresses the importance of careful discernment, not blindly believing the possessed or the demon's words, and the need for the exorcist's personal purity and prudence. Cases of a deceived priest and a knight's pact illustrate the dangers of credulity and the demon's cunning in exploiting human weaknesses.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXXII: Du côté naturel de la guérison des possédés, des métamorphoses, des aggravations, des intermittences et des métastases du mal, surtout quand il est vers sa fin. Saint Norbert.
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines the 'natural side' of healing from possession, acknowledging the physical and psychological aspects of the malady. It discusses phenomena like metamorphoses (changes in the body), aggravations (worsening symptoms), intermittences (periodic relief), and metastases (shifting of symptoms or demonic influence). The case of Saint Norbert illustrates how the healing process can be complex, often involving a combination of spiritual intervention and natural restoration, especially towards the end of the demonic influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXXIII: Des crises de la maladie. Elles s'opèrent par les évacuations alvines, par les reins, par les sueurs, par les poumons, par les vomissements, où les possédés rejettent souvent des reptiles ou d'autres choses extraordinaires.
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes the 'crises' or turning points in the possession, characterized by various bodily evacuations (feces, urine, sweat, vomiting). It details instances where the possessed expel unusual substances (reptiles, stones, charcoals, insects, black liquid), attributing these to the demon's departure or the corruption it inflicted. These phenomena are explained as both physical manifestations of internal turmoil and symbolic expressions of the infernal spirit's presence and departure.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XXXIV: Des crises spirituelles. Crises dans les régions intermédiaires. Contre-épreuve de la guérison. La bienheureuse Eustochie.
structure_content.summary: This chapter focuses on the 'spiritual crises' experienced during possession, particularly in the 'intermediate regions' of the human being (imagination, sensation). These crises involve intense visions and illusions that precede deliverance, often serving as a counter-test for healing. The experience of the Blessed Eustochie is revisited, emphasizing how her spiritual fortitude and divine grace allowed her to overcome these final demonic assaults, leading to a profound inner healing despite continued physical torment.

key_concepts.definition: The infernal counterpart to divine mysticism, characterized by humanity's inclination towards evil and the subsequent establishment of rapport with demonic forces.

A state where an external evil spirit takes control of an individual's body, mind, or both, often facilitated by moral failings (sins) or specific physical and psychological predispositions. It is described as a 'maladie diabolique' with physical and spiritual symptoms.

A voluntary act driven by human will to achieve culpable intentions through external means, often by establishing rapport with 'radical evil' and utilizing natural forces in an unnatural way, but ultimately a form of enslavement to the demon.

A set of practices and exercises, mirroring religious asceticism but perverted, aimed at introducing an individual to the 'regions of the abyss' and initiating them into infernal mysteries, often through sensory excitation and self-abandonment to vice.

The original evil principle, not created by God but given being through the free will of a created intelligence (Satan), which then seeks to propagate itself and infect human nature, becoming the root cause of physical and moral evil.

A state of heightened, but corrupted, perception induced by diabolical practices, allowing one to 'see' distant events or hidden truths, often accompanied by illusions and distorted understanding, as it originates from the 'realm of shadows' or the demon.

A gathering point for witches, where they are said to meet, influenced either physically or through vivid, powerful illusions induced by magical ointments or demonic influence, involving blasphemous rites and forbidden pleasures.

Specific unguents made from various narcotic and toxic plants (e.g., hemlock, henbane, solanum, mandragora, aconite) and animal components (e.g., bat blood, animal fat), applied to the body to induce lethargy, vivid dreams, and sensations of flight, facilitating the illusory experience of the Sabbath.

A formal or tacit agreement between a human and a demon, involving the renunciation of God and allegiance to the demon in exchange for temporal power, wealth, knowledge, or satisfaction of desires. It is viewed as a perverse counter-part to the baptismal covenant.

The initial, less profound stage of demonic influence, characterized by external attacks, physical vexations, and mental agitation, which can sometimes escalate into full possession if unchecked or if the individual yields to the evil promptings.

The shifting of demonic activity or symptoms, either within an individual's body (e.g., from one organ to another, causing different physical ailments) or between individuals, reflecting the mobility of the 'malady'.

The ritual practice of the Church to expel demons from possessed individuals, using prayers, sacred objects (cross, relics, holy water), sacraments (confession, Eucharist), and invoking the name of Jesus Christ, relying on divine authority to break the demonic hold and restore the individual.

The phenomenon where possessed individuals speak in foreign or unknown languages, or manifest multiple voices, often used by demons to convey blasphemies, reveal hidden secrets, or engage in theological arguments, demonstrating the demon's intelligence and influence.

Described as the central point of entry and operation for demonic possession, influencing vital functions and mental processes, and often affected by diabolical practices to produce extraordinary phenomena.

practical_system.description: The book describes 'diabolical asceticism' and related practices not as a system to be followed, but as the process through which individuals voluntarily or through various predispositions (moral failings, temperament) open themselves to demonic influence. This 'system' aims to achieve a perverse union with 'radical evil' and Satan, manifesting in effects like clairvoyance, physical alterations, and the ability to perform acts contrary to natural laws, often through ritualistic means. The author presents these practices as a descent into the 'regions of the abyss,' serving diabolical ends, and condemns them as such.
tools: Substances: Witches' ointments (composed of hemlock, henbane, solanum, mandragora, aconite, bat blood, animal fat), various plant extracts (visoccan, tabac, coca), poisons (arsenic, ciguë).
Instruments: Tambours, bells, sabers, lances, knives (for self-mutilation), mirrors, crystals, fluids (ink).
Symbolic Items: Paper with magical formulas, images of deities or demons, specific plants, animal parts.

Environmental Elements: Specific places (crossroads, grottos, isolated forests), fire, darkness. (Note: Sacred objects like crosses, relics, and consecrated hosts are described as tools for *exorcism*, used *against* diabolical magic, not by its practitioners.)
rituals: Sensory Excitation: Ingesting hallucinogenic plants (chanvre, tabac, coca), toxic substances (arsenic), or potent alcohol to induce altered states, visions, and temporary insensitivity to pain.
Rhythmic Movement: Engaging in frenzied dances and cadenced movements, often accompanied by specific chants or music, to reach ecstatic or trance states and attract spirits.

Physical Manipulation: Applying magical ointments (composed of narcotic and toxic plants, animal blood/fat) to the body for prolonged lethargy, vivid dreams, or the sensation of astral travel (e.g., to the Sabbat).

Evocation of Spirits: Using specific formulas, names, and objects (e.g., drawing circles, burning incense, manipulating images) to summon demons or the spirits of the dead for purposes like gaining knowledge, wealth, or revenge.

Formal Pacts: Entering into explicit or implicit agreements with demons, often involving renunciation of religious vows, signing with blood, and committing to service in exchange for temporal power or satisfaction of desires.
Contempt for the Sacred: Deliberately profaning sacred objects and religious practices, using them in inverted ways, or engaging in blasphemous rites as a sign of allegiance to the demonic.

relevant_quotes.text: La révélation, l'histoire, l'étude de la nature démontrent que tous les domaines de la création visible ou invisible sont partagés, d'après un ancien symbole, en deux royaumes, celui de la lumière et celui des ténèbres, et que l'homme, placé entre les deux, a pris part aussi à cette division; de sorte que son être penche des deux côtés, et est accessible aux influences qui partent de ces deux régions opposées.
Tout exemplaire de cet ouvrage, non revêtu de ma signature, sera réputé contrefait.

Ce qui dans le premier cas possède, et se laisse posséder au contraire dans le second, c'est le mal radical. Ce mal n'a point en soi de raison d'être; car il n'a pas été créé de Dieu. Tout être, ayant été créé de Dieu, est bon : le mal étant donc le non-bien est par là même non-être, c'est-à-dire une pure négation. Pour qu'il acquière l'être qui lui manque, il faut qu'il s'attache à quelque chose qui l'a déjà : en d'autres termes il doit se produire dans un être personnel, qui lui communique une raison d'être, et lui donne ainsi une réalité. Le mal n'est pas, mais le mauvais existe.
L'ascèse diabolique... le but de l'ascèse infernale, de toutes ses initiations et de tous ses mystères, c'est de conduire l'homme dans les régions ténébreuses de l'abîme.

Les mauvaises passions se sont tellement emparées de plusieurs hommes qu'abusant des dons de la nature ils en font des onguents magiques en les mêlant ensemble. Quoiqu'il y ait en tout cela beaucoup de superstition, il est certain néanmoins que ces substances sont naturellement très-actives.

Quiconque veut faire partie d'un état politique doit se soumettre aux lois qui le gouvernent. Il prend sur lui des devoirs en échange des droits qu'il reçoit, et s'engage à certaines redevances envers le chef de l'État, afin d'obtenir sa protection et son appui. Il en est ainsi pour celui qui entre dans cette communion des méchants, laquelle est la contre-partie de la communion des saints...

Dans la possession, ce lien est brisé bien souvent, et les vaisseaux capillaires semblent devenir le centre d'un mouvement particulier et plus ou moins bizarre. C'est là ce qui explique ces caprices, ce vague et cette incertitude dans toutes les fonctions vitales que l'on remarque chez beaucoup de possédés.

La possession, de même que toutes les autres maladies, a ses crises qui conduisent par des degrés plus ou moins appréciables à la guérison parfaite. Ces crises se produisent sous les formes les plus diverses, et affectent souvent l'un des organes par lesquels s'opèrent les sécrétions du corps humain.

critical_analysis.relevance: This volume, focusing on 'diabolical mysticism,' is highly relevant for understanding historical perspectives on demonology, witchcraft, and possession within Western Esotericism. Gorres meticulously documents numerous cases, drawing from both theological and secular sources of his time, providing a rich repository of historical accounts of magical practices, alleged demonic interventions, and exorcisms. His attempt to categorize and explain these phenomena, even if through a lens of moral condemnation and theological bias, offers insights into the societal, psychological, and physiological interpretations of altered states and malevolent influences before modern psychology. The contrast he draws between divine and diabolical mysticism, and his detailed descriptions of the 'ascèse diabolique,' contribute to a structured understanding of negative magical traditions from a historical academic viewpoint.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience would be academic researchers and historians specializing in the history of religion, demonology, and Western Esotericism, seeking primary and secondary accounts of magical practices and possession narratives. Occult practitioners might also find it useful for historical context and comparative studies of different magical traditions, but not as a practical manual due to its critical, condemnatory tone and the author's clear intention to present these practices as evil and to be avoided. The detailed case studies also make it relevant for scholars interested in the intersection of religion, medicine, and psychology in past centuries.
